'''Curley James Weaver''' (March 25, 1906 - September 20, 1962<ref name="Dead">[http://users.efortress.com/doc-rock/1960.html User.efortress.com - accessed May 2009]</ref>) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[musician]], also known as '''Slim Gordon'''.

==Biography==
===Early years===
He was born in [[Covington, Georgia|Covington]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States]],<ref name="Dead"/> and raised on a farm near [[Porterdale, Georgia|Porterdale]].  His mother, Savannah "Dip" Shepard Weaver, was a well-respected [[pianist]] and [[guitarist]], who taught Curley together with her friend's sons, [[Barbecue Bob|"Barbecue Bob" Hicks]] and [[Charley Lincoln|Charlie Hicks]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]]
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 182
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>  The three formed a group with [[harmonica]] player [[Eddie Mapp]], and played in the local area.<ref name="russell"/>

===Early career===
In 1925 Weaver moved to [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], working as a laborer and playing on the streets and at various social events.<ref name="Trail">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebluestrail.com/artists/mus_cw.htm |title=Curly (sic) Weaver |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Thebluestrail.com |accessdate=November 19, 2011}}</ref>  In 1928, he first [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] with [[Columbia Records]], later releasing [[gramophone record|records]] on several different [[record label]]s.  Although he recorded on his own during the 1920s and 1930s, first in the style taught by his mother and later with the spreading [[Piedmont]] style, he was best known for [[duet (music)|duets]] with [[Blind Willie McTell]] - with whom he worked until the 1950s - as well as [[Barbecue Bob]], Fred McMullen, and harmonica and [[guitar]] player [[Buddy Moss]].<ref name="russell"/>  He was also a member of the recording groups The Georgia Browns (Weaver, Moss, McMullen) and The Georgia Cotton Pickers (Bob, Weaver, Moss), examples of the sort of bands that played house parties in those days.<ref name="russell"/>

===Later years===
After [[World War II]] he recorded in [[New York City|New York]] and [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]] both [[solo (music)|solo]], and with McTell.<ref name="russell"/>  His final [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] were in 1949.  Weaver lost his [[blindness|sight]] in the 1950s after working on the railroad, and died of [[uremia]]<ref name="Dead"/> in Almon, Georgia,<ref>[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p31537|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic.com - accessed May 2009]</ref> in 1962, at the age of 56.

===Children===
His daughter Cora Mae Bryant (born May 1, 1926) continued in her father's tradition as a blues musician until her own death in late 2008.
